description:
We were looking for a place that had fresh spring rolls in Chinatown and came across this small Vietnamese place and decided to try it after checking out the menu. It's mostly your standard Vietnamese cuisine of noodles and rice, soups and rolls and clay pots. We both picked out a vermicelli bowl each (vegetable for me, bbq pork for my partner) as well as an order of fresh vegetable spring rolls. 

The rolls arrived first, as expected. The four rolls came with a sweet chili dipping sauce and were big and fat and full of fresh vegetables (mushrooms, lettuce, mint, some tofu, and not a lot of noodles surprisingly). They were very good and went great with the sauce.

Our bowls came out not long after and I was quite shocked at the volume of food in both! I was also extremely impressed with the vegetable bowl, which was heaped with fried cabbage, mushrooms and tofu. Many places fall short in their vegetable bowls with a few boring vegetables and being very bland on taste, but this was bursting with flavour. I barely needed the extra sweet chili sauce that came with it (although I poured it in to seep through to the noodles underneath). My partner's bowl came topped with bbq pork and sprouts which he said was excellent and done really well. There was also so much food, we couldn't even come close to eating half of what we were served (we might've been able to eat more if we hadn't had the spring rolls?) Given how cheap the prices were though, we didn't feel bad leaving food behind, we gave it our best shot and ate until we were stuffed.

Pros: excellent food, the vegetable vermicelli bowl is delicious, huge portions for really cheap prices.
Cons: not a lot of vegetarian options overall, so be aware of this.
author: Cassandra J.

description: Food was excellent and so was the service. Will be visiting this place again. Soup and clay pot rice was delicious.
author: Michele R.

description: Nice neighborhood restaurant. This is a Chinese owned Vietnamese restaurant.  They have pho, spring rolls and rice plates.  Flavors are pretty authentic as to what I am used to in Hawaii.  Price point for each entree is between 8 to 9 dollars. Meals are prepared upon taking your order. Mostly neighborhood people come here to support this small business,
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Recently beat the flu, so instead of my usual gym session after work, I decided to take a break this week and treat myself to some hot pho on this cold, cloudy day. 

Found a place on yelp that had 3 1/2 stars which wasn't too bad compared to the next Vietnamese place with 2 stars. Ordered the pho special which was $9 so that wasn't bad at all. The Pho came out piping hot which I like and had a nice glisten to the soup-all good signals. HOWEVER, I was instantly disappointed when I tasted the soup. It lacked so much flavor. I had to add extra hoisin and sirarcha just to scrap up whatever flavor I could get. 

And this place got 3 1/2 stars? Don't get me wrong, the ladies were nice AND they accepted credit cards but damn... I can't let the food slide. 

Would I be back? Most definitely not. I guess I'll have to walk much further to find a decent pho spot to go to when I have the craving. 

Might have to grab a golden boys slice just to satisfy my tastebuds...bummer
author: Michael T.

description:
Pho Vung Tau is a Vietnamese restaurant located in the Russian Hill area. Now I wouldn't say this place is a "Vietnamese" restaurant because their food tastes like Chinese food (Chinese food is awesome btw). 

I came here and ordered #45 on the menu. The meat was delicious, the egg roll was awesome, the fish sauce was authentic but the noodles did not taste like Vietnamese noodles at all. Tastes like the Chinese noodles from Chinese restaurants. They give a lot but I would definitely try something else. 

Overall, great food, customer service but not so great noodles.
author: Jonathan Z.

description: I didnt like the noodle much.... not much pho flavor that i can taste... i love the beef balls though.... although i ordered the special pho but it doesnt look special in anyway... coffee was ok... love their menu looking stylish....
author: Michael P.

description:
My mom recommended I give this place a try, so I ended up going twice in the same week to try different dishes. The restaurant is relatively small, but has sufficient seating to take care of most of the lunch crowd.

Beef Pho: I was rather underwhelmed. Portions are fine, meat is a bit sparse, and soup was likely the least flavorful pho broth I've had. Noodles were average, nothing special but not bad either.
Bun w/ BBQ beef + Imperial Rolls: Much better than the pho in my opinion. Great portion sizes, beef is tender and flavorful, and the imperial rolls are done quite well. I would definitely come back again to try some of their other BBQ meats and also 

They place their health department score card (81 points) close to the counter, so you don't really see it until you're right at the table. For a quick and reasonably priced meal however I would definitely come back again for some more Bun.
author: Michael L.

description:
I stopped by two weeks ago one weekday evening since I was craving for some pho and it was cold outside. When I came in, there weren't many people there inside; I counted single digits including the workers in the kitchen. I was seated immediately and served some hot tea. I looked at the menu and ordered the barbeque chicken pho. Ten minutes later, my pho came out with a side of vegetables and barbeque chicken. 

For some reason, I thought that the barbeque chicken would be on the pho instead of being plated separately, but that's a non-issue. I dug in and sampled the broth first and I was surprised by the strong taste. I couldn't quite put my finger on what it is, but it did taste saltier than other phos I've had. Does not taste like the pho that I am used to. I poured in the accompanying vegetables and went for the noodles. The rice noodles were good, and the so were the vegetables. I then moved onto the barbeque chicken (there were eight strips) and I admired the crunchy skin and juicy meat. This was a hearty bowl of pho, and I was pretty full by the end of the meal. 

Some observations that I'd like to point is that the pho broth is not like other restaurants, and I have to assume that the pho broth is standardized for other menu items since the protein is coming out as a side. One reason I say that is because I felt that I did not get a taste of chicken from the broth itself. I can't really tell you what the broth is made from, but I don't think it's a chicken-based broth. Also, as an aside, I rather they put the napkins on the table instead of having me flag down the waitress to ask for extra napkins, but I think that's a common practice in Chinatown restaurants. 

In my opinion, the pho itself is a three, but really the saving grace here was the barbeque chicken. There was a generous helping of barbeque chicken and it helped balance out my mild dislike of pho broth. Therefore, I am awarding a plus one based on how good the barbeque chicken is. In my opinion, I think you can get better pho in Chinatown for nine dollars. The taste of the broth sort of turned me off, and I don't think I would come back for the pho. However, the barbeque chicken tells me that the other non-pho dishes in this restaurant are worth exploring.
author: Nelson X.

description: Pho makes me happy lol. With so many restaurants in San Fran to choose from this one stuck out. I was the first customer of the day. The workers and I believe the lady was the owner were very nice! I ordered the #20 and the fresh shrimp rolls. Those rolls were Heaven sent! The dipping sauce that came with it, OMG, delicious!!!! My pho was pretty good too. The broth was flavorful, fresh, and hot! Just what I needed on this chilly day. I added some Hoisin and Sriracha to it. It also came with bean sprouts and basil. The restaurant was small, cozy, and clean. The restaurant was in China town so I was able to explore the area a little too.
author: Joiya A.

description: Hands down the best in the neighborhood since Vietnam closed on broadway. We all love it. We have tried about half the menu and nothing has disappointed. The Pho is bomb! Not expensive AT ALL. This is were we go out when we want great food without breaking our budge!
author: Krishna M.

description:
I was so sad when they closed down on Kearny St. I always craved for their clay pots here. It's sooo good. My dad told us to try a new place on Vallejo St so we went. I thought the waitress looked familiar but couldn't pinpoint where I saw her before. She recognized us immediately and even remembered what our usual orders were. We were so glad to find the place that makes the best clay pots to match our taste!

Def coming back to this spot (even though it's further away from us now)
author: Priscilla D.

description: Happy to stumble across this restaurant. It can get very crowded during lunch time which is when I went. The food came out fast and tasty. Plus the ladies that work there were super friendly and nice!
author: Karen V.

description: I ordered shrimp over vermicelli , they put only 5 shrimps in the bowl , the rest was all vermicelli ; they are trying to save money that way . Also ordered eggplant chicken over rice , was extremely greasy . Waste of money in this place . Won't eat here again
author: Hnia K.

description: Amazing fresh spring rolls full of basil!! Delicious Pho!! Nice Staff!! Definitely would be back!
author: B N.

description:
Since I started working in the Financial district over 2 years ago, I've been coming to this place at least once a week, when they were still on Kearny.
All of a sudden, they close down for renovation and vacation, and another noodle place takes its place. I was so shocked!
Just a little over a month ago I found out they moved to Vallejo st, which is quite a bit further for me, but I was excited to go back.

Yes, I've found an eyelash in chow fun recently, and there was a fly which may or may not have been cooked into a piece of meat, but my overall experience is good with this place. Shit happens, I'm not gonna complain about 1 bad minor experience. 

I usually get the #40, vermicelli with chicken and shrimp. It's somewhere around the $8.50 range, so with tip and tax I usually pay 10-11 bucks, which isn't bad at all. The taste is familiar to another Vietnamese place I frequented in San Bruno when I worked around there.
I'd rather walk 15mins to Chinatown/North Beach than pay for an overpriced salad at Mixt Green. I want my carbs!
I've had the Pho Ga, here plenty of times, not the best pho I've had but it's decent and well priced. I also enjoy the Combination Fried Rice and Vietnamese Clay Pot dish. I dont' think I've ever spent more than 12 bucks here for lunch (I don't order a drink, just stick to water or tea).

Now that I know they're back, I'll be coming here at least once a week to get my Vietnamese food fix!
author: Mike O.

description: I thoroughly enjoyed the food here. My meal arrived quickly. I had the simple beef pho and I had no problems with it. The place was very clean and the staff was friendly. At first they had a few problems with my service dog, but that may have just been a misunderstanding. Once we got that cleared up there were no problems with her.
author: Murphy H.

description:
So I already posted this when I checked in, but this place is awesome!!!! I got the chicken pho, it was supposed to be spicy but it wasn't but that's fine. Either way, this was delicious!!! 

First of all, it was a mountain of food!!! One bowl could have fed two or three people! Not that you'd want to share because it was awesome. It was a nice broth, the noodles weren't slimy, and the chicken was delicious. 

The bean sprouts added a crunchiness that's hard to get in a noodle soup, and I loved it. This was my first time trying pho, but it won't be the last time. 

What I got for $8 here I could have easily paid $15-$25 for somewhere else (I know, I've paid that much for ramen, and less if it), it was good and for my buck, and I regret NOTHING!!!
author: Amber T.

description:
Pho here was okay but the combo meals were better. Service was prompt and plus that they take credit cards.

I got the beef pho ($8) which came in a really large serving size. The brisket and noodles were tasty. The beef balls and broth could have used a little more flavor. My friend got the BBQ pork combo ($8) that came with fried shrimp which I thought was better. The pork was very tender and savory.

Overall good prices and solid food but nothing that stood out.
author: Linda X.

description:
Must be customize your own soup because the soup is so bland I had to drown it with hoisin and sirarcha!!!!!!!!!

I usually don't write reviews for restaurants but I just have buyers remorse. So I came here around late afternoon and was worn out for the day and it was closer than walking all the way to Golden Star and decided to try this place out. Read some reviews, saw some pictures and thought it would be a pretty decent place. First off, the pho here is way too overpriced, $8/bowl?????? For only some not-so-decent pho! It contained very little quantity of meat in my beef pho noodle soup. I probably would've been better off with a rice plate.
author: Vanessa Z.

description:
The portions are huge here. I got the chicken flat noodle soup. I barely touched it and I was so full so you're definitely getting a lot of food for a super reasonable price. The waitresses were very friendly and attentive. The place filled up fast at lunch time on a weekday but they were on top of it the whole time. 

The taste overall was alright. I've had chicken noodle soups with amazing broth, which can really make or break noodle soups, but this was mediocre in comparison. I wish it were lighter and the broth didn't have much chicken flavor. There was definitely much more noodles than chicken.
author: Kelly N.

description:
81 on the Health Department Score Card. Bowl of Pho and Imperial Rolls? A hair under 16 bucks. Plenty crowded on a Monday night at 7:00. I wanted to imagine this as the well-kept neighborhood secret, but it's probably best if people don't know about it. 

I had a much better experience with another Vietnamese place just around the corner on Broadway.
author: West R.

description: Disappointed by the bahn mi.  The Bbq pork was mostly fat and gristle.  I walked away still hungry.  Tasteless flavorless inedible.  See photos. I may give the pho a try but never again for the sandwich.  How can the $4 I dropped here get so little substance and flavor? JYW is sad
author: Jeff W.

description:
This is the place for my main go to for Pho. Excellent quality, Excellent service, and Excellent staff. I have been eating Pho here since it's been open. The flavor is super rich in the broth and the quantity is super reasonable for its affordable price. 

Great for a cold day to warm up your tummy or to recover from a hangover last night. I bet you won't regret it.
author: Judy M.

description: Cheap, unique, fast and delicious in San Francisco? SCORE! My friend and I stopped in for a quick bite before the comedy show at Cobbs. I ordered the number 30, chicken satay soup. It was so delicious chock full of bean sprouts, chicken, spiciness, and mild nutty flavor. I can't wait to go back there and have it again!
author: Lisa B.

description: This restaurant had the WORST service ever!!!!   After waiting for 20 min before they decided to take our order ..  the food came and seemed ok ...  after a few bites we heard a 10 year old boy yell ..  "Holy Shit" he ran around his table and proceeded to stomp on a 3 inch cockroach while the entire restaurant looked on in horror!!   The waitress laughed and walked over to the dead roach and picked it up with the towel she was wiping the tables down with .   We immediately got  up to pay the bill and was not even offered an apology for what we just witnessed...   worst place EVER !!!!
author: Yvonne C.

description: Late lunch,  promptly sat,  ordered the pork and shrimp rolls,  pho and bun rieu.  The pork and shrimp rolls were pretty good but we were also starving.  The pho was OK,  soup base was a tad salty and they used a lot of star anise which over powered the soup.  The bun rieu was OK,  different from what I'm used to.  They had a lot of ground pork but not a lot shrimp or even crab roe.  A few pieces of tomatoes and it's not as pungent as I used to.  Service friendly and efficient.  Prices very affordable .
author: Alicia A.

description:
Gets a 3 star just because the imperial rolls (#1) and the service was alright. 

Boyfriend got beef pho with bun bo hue soup base for an extra $1, I got bbq chicken pho with flat noodle. 

First, the pho had absolutely no taste/flavor. Adding the chicken into the soup made no difference. Our soups tasted like spicy water and plain water with oil. 

First bite and I could not bare to eat anymore. The service was fine. Nothing bad to say about it. But the phos  were absolutely flavorless. The flat noodles had a nice chewy texture but because of the soup, it tasted bland. 

Other tables with rice plates or vermicelli looked pretty appetizing. But the soup.... don't let the photos deceive you.
author: Angela M.

description: The service here was horrible.  Food was mediocre.  When we were there it was not crowded at all, yet we had to constantly remind the waitress for some water and napkins.  When they brought out the napkins, they only gave us ONE, when we had a party of 9. Stingy much? Definitely will not be coming back here.
author: Michael T.

description:
I have mixed reactions on both of my visits to this Vietnamese restaurant in North Beach. 

My first visit and checked in was dinner time. I ordered 5-spice Chicken and cold vermicelli bowl (#43). For $7.95, I get grilled and seasoned chicken pieces, egg rolls, cold pasta and vegetables in a bowl. The charred chicken pieces and egg roll were still piping hot upon my arrival to my table. And those pieces are very good and 
incorporated very well with the other ingredients. 

My second visit was a few nights later. I ordered the BBQ Beef over white rice (#58). For $6.95, I get grilled seasoned beef with white rice and side of salad.  For the price, this is a very hearty portion. But the beef was dry as jerky. Plus the chef cut the pieces for me before landed on my plate. That was nice of them to do that, but I wished the chef did not cut the meat for me. "It's not like I am going stab anybody!"

The Cantonese people were very nice to Joe Cool and refilled my tea and water often. Dogs do get thirsty too. 

This place is very quiet compare to the other Vietnamese restaurants in the area. I may try other dishes though and skip the rice dishes.
author: Matt G.

description: Got the chicken pho... gross. Broth tasted bad, only had a few slices of chicken most of which didn't look edible.
author: Jackie L.

description: Saddest tasting pho, service was okay, came in an hour before close... some of the menu items were unavailable, do yourself a favour and avoid this place for soup. Rice dishes and vermicelli dishes look decent though.
author: Kevin N.

description:
I only come here for takeout when I'm off work late and don't want to cook at home. 

You get a healthy portion size for the price. I've tried the pho, vermicelli bowls, and rice plates - all are good! My go-to here is the pho and vermicelli bowls. 

The only negative - the imperial rolls and spring rolls here aren't that great.

From what I see as I wait for my takeout, the service is friendly and attentive. They also take credit card with no minimum (that I'm aware of), so that's a plus.
author: Kerry D.

description: The food was pretty amazing for the price we got a referral from a local suspended for 40 years and you can't beat the local referral of a different recommended everything was good
author: Rodney S.

description:
I consistently get exactly what I expect. I expect a healthy sized, fairly priced, bowl of noodles with the best broth around, and I've looked around. I'm getting #20 - special beef Pho.

I've been working in different offices around SF. I'll only exaggerate slightly saying that being close to this place is a criteria when choosing employment opportunity.
I'm here at least once a week.
Service is quick and kind.

Love this place!

Please make sure you are expecting a home style, typical, Pho place before judging this place harshly.
author: Alex C.

description:
Don't serve Bun Bo Hue if you don't know how to make it.  Giving me raw jalapeño peppers does not add to the flavor and definitely not spice level.  Sucks.  Will NEVER return.

The combo special pho was also flavorless, little noodles & meat.

Time to close down.  Cook what you know and stop cheating customers.
author: Gloria H.

description:
That moment you find a strand of thick hair in your imperial roll. 

You wonder, what part of the body did it come from? What else did I put in my mouth?? 

And suddenly, their tasty food doesn't seem so tasty anymore. Suddenly your great day doesn't seem so great. And the blue skies seem a little less blue.
author: Jenelly D.

description: The food servings tend to be larger than other pho places in the same area. Overall the tastes was pretty average but the sauces should be avoided, seeing that there were flies flying above the containers.
author: Joy L.

description:
Dropped by for a quick dinner before a basketball game.  I ordered the combination C meal which came with salad, rice, fried shrimp,  fried rolls,  beef slices and the vinegar dipping.  Service was friendly and the meal was satisfying.   My mom and sister enjoyed the shrimp and pork clay pot.  

Combo C is $8.99
Shrimp and pork clay pot $8.99 each
author: E. C.

description:
The sweet smells of cinnamon and star anise always seem to seep out the restaurant as I walk by in the evening so I was excited to stop by for some pho on this chilly day. 

In short, the serving sizes are large and the folks are nice and attentive but while it's not the best pho in the city, it more than suffices to fulfill a pho craving. I ordered the special beef pho which is basically the combo and they are generous with the ingredients. It's a big bowl with lots of broth which was great but I thought it wasn't as complex and layered in flavor as some other places. Still it met my need for some soupy comfort food. 

My friend liked his combo plate and I saw they have bahn mi sandwiches for $3.50. Will be back to grab some of those in the future especially since they open late in Chinatown - a rarity indeed.
author: Jon L.

description: Came here to try Vnese Pho and it's kinda good. It's located around my work, so I will be back definitely.
author: Khoe T.

description:
It's hard to comprehend the bad reviews. This place is solid in my book.

While the service wasn't mind blowing (what place in Chinatown is!?), it was prompt and decent enough. 

As I've said in other reviews, and I'll say again here, I know GOOD Vietnamese food. I also know  Chinese-Vietnamese food.... Which, let's be honest here, is quite different.

I can't rate the pho, but the bun bo hue is top notch.... In the ranks of some SJ favorites. The bowl is massive, the broth is wonderful and there is a TON of meet. For a whopping $7, youll  be sweating out last night's decisions in no time. 

What justifies the review? THEY TAKE CREDIT CARD. Yeah, I said it. Unheard of.

For under $10 out the door, you'll be feeling refreshed, full and have some newly acquired soup stains on your crisp dress shirt.

Thank me later.
author: Ryan L.

description: Good clay pot rice that forms a yummy crust at the end. Grilled pork is actually fried pork patty. YUCK -- work aprons hanging in the bathroom & said room subdivided into storage behind curtain.
author: V L.

description: Went here about Lunchtime on a weekday, kind of busy but fast enough service, they take credit cards here thats a plus. The phos are great, big bowls for just less than $10. People come for the pho, but today we came for the combo meals of pork bbq and shrimp which was delicious!!! Will come back here if were around the area!
author: Katherine J.

description:
Overall I give this place 2 stars. 

One star for it being reasonably priced 
One star for the food coming out quickly.

Decided to come here with the family since we were in the area. I ordered Beef noodle soup and it came out pretty quick. I ate some and I have to admit, it was pretty plain tasting. After I added some sriracha sauce, it was a little better. After a few minutes of eating and slurping some noodles... Or what I thought was noodles, I felt and noticed something weird. I was eating PLASTIC!!! There was a LONG THICK plastic in my bowl of soup. I quickly told the waitress and she gladly exchanged it for a new one. I wish she would have said sorry or acknowledged the situation better. She said nothing as she took my bowl. Safe to say I won't be back.
author: L Q.

description:
There are those times when I wish I rely less on Yelp and more on instinct for my dinner here turned out to be a huge mistake.  First off, the customers dining in when I visited recently were all non-Asian.  At a peak dinner hour that should have raised a red flag, but I stayed anyway because I was hungry and I was curious.  I had just hiked down from Van Ness Avenue and Sacramento Street after volunteering at a One Brick event, and not having had lunch I was starved.

When I heard the gentleman seated adjacent to me carry on in loud conversation to both his dining companion and before him to the waitress that his chow fun was nothing like chow fun he had ordered at other restaurants that should have been the second red flag.  By the way the waitress snapped back with a bit of attitude telling the senior gentleman that THAT was the way they prepared THEIR chow fun.

From hearing that I knew I wasn't ordering chow fun so I decided on one of their combination rice plates instead.  I thought I was going with a safer choice by selecting the combination rice plate with grilled pork chop, lemongrass chicken and a fried egg.  There was a television turned to the local news so that kept me occupied as I waited for my food.

The kitchen worked at a snail's pace, and I waited some time before I was presented with this plate of what looked like a very good meal (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/IiawLo4puLiRPqYssFC1_w?select=I-8MejlhcLwwSKlQfkBFeA).  Looks can be so deceiving though, and there was no way of telling that from just looking at this plate.

How was my dinner you ask?

The rice was overcooked.  Inedible!  I hate mushy rice, and I never understand how a restaurant can mess up on such a simple staple like steamed rice.  When I first learned how to cook, rice was the one thing that came out perfect.  The pickled carrots and daikon wreaked.  Somehow I wouldn't be surprised if somebody told me they used the same vinegar brine over and over again.  It was just plain bad!  The quarter inch thin pork chop was tough and 40 percent of the cut was either bone, fat or sinew.  The two pieces of lemongrass chicken thigh (obviously reheated in a microwave) were the size of two thumbs.  The fried egg was overcooked.  If there was one redeeming quality on this entire plate of food it was probably that the lettuce leaf was fresh and the two slices of room temperature cucumber were crunchy.

The service was awful too.  Even though I threw in the towel or in this case my napkin onto the dinner plate very quickly the waitress walked by twice staring down on my table without bringing me my check.  I had to walk up to their little counter, ask for my check then wait for the only person capable of handling the cash register to arrive before I could pay and get change.

The only thing this visit did for me was it quieted my growling intestines long enough for me to take the short walk up to Golden Boy Pizza where I pigged out on delicious pizza squares instead.  

Cheap food - yes!  Edible food - no!  Never again, Pho Vung Tau!!
author: Wilhelm Y.

description: Clean and bright inside despite lack of curbside appeal, entrees mainly noodle soups, grilled meats (BBQ pork was very tender and flavorful) and rice plates. No msg. Food solid and everything's about $7-8.
author: Nancy H.

description: My parents and I had dinner at this place one evening and it was pretty good as far as portion size and taste. This evening I called for take out and was looking forward to a great meal. I picked up my order 15 minutes after calling it in. When I got home and was ready to eat, I ordered No. 43, BBQ chicken/Imperial rolls vermicelli, I saw five small charred pieces of BBQ chicken and six small inch sized, burnt imperial rolls on a bed of rice noodles, one small chopped lettuce leaf, a few pieces of bean sprouts, cucumbers and maybe four tiny pieces of mint leaves. I was disappointed, that small, charcoal order was almost $10.00 (including tax). I also ordered the No. 10, BBQ beef sandwich, another disappointment.  A few small strips of BBQ beef, a pinch of pickled carrots and turnip folded into a french roll, which was decent.  I will never order another sandwich from this place again. I would drive over to Larkin St. where a couple of decent Vietnamese bahn mi shops are located. I'm not to sure about eating at the restaurant ever again, if I do, I will definitely ask them not to burn or char my food, again.
author: Gina L.

description:
3/7/14  Lunch

Vietnamese restaurants are competitive in this town. Just in Chinatown alone there are 8. I came to Pho Vung Tau purely out of convenience as I have a meeting nearby. I have remembered always seeing the place packed. But sadly I have my expectation a bit too high.

Dry vermicelli with BBQ pork and imperial rolls ($7.35) is my standard affair. I only opt for pho on a cold rainy day. The pork is very thinly sliced but marinated and tasty. The problem is the "lumpia-size" rolls. Tiny like those brass Thai nails on Thai dancers! It's mostly fried skin/wonton wrapper with very little filling in it. Not good.

Looks like Little Paris still has the best rolls in Chinatown, My Canh not bad either. I thought Golden King has small rolls but Pho Yung Tau's is piteously small. Meh.

Cash only.
author: Matt Y.

description: My go to for pho in north beach.  I usually get the pho ga, which meets expectations, but recently I tried the BBQ beef, and that was just right.  I usually order in- good price and they always are on the ball.  A little pho ga cures all that ails.  I can't tell where that huge photo on the wall is from though
author: Charles C.

description:
Love it! Cheap, fast and good.
Service sucks though. Be prepared for that.
Otherwise, some of my all-time favorite orders here are the....

1. Grilled shrimp and imperial rolls vermicelli bun! So fresh, filling and cheap. 7.35
2. Satay chicken noodle soup. Hella unique, huge bowl of noodles, and awesome chicken 6.95 ish
3. Catfish soup. On the pricey side, 8.95, but so good. Hot, Tangy, fresh. 

Great food!
author: michelle w.

description: Good reasonably priced food.  Good portions and straightforward menu.  CASH ONLY, though, so be prepared.  They also are closed Sunday.  Beef & Chicken Phos are faves, but BBQ meat plates are also yummy.
author: Mitzi A.

description:
The place was pretty packed whenever we came in for lunch, but we got a table quick. Mom got the Special Beef Pho while I got the BBQ Chicken Pho w/ fishballs. 

Service was okay. The pho was alright. I felt like the BBQ Chicken was a bit too salty.

My fave Pho place is still PPQ.
author: Amy C.

description: I have never had Pho is California before but I was impressed with it at this restaurant. It was delicious, however I got one of the options with the chili pepper next to it, hoping for a spicier soup and I could barely tell if there was any spice. However the food still tasted amazing and the bowl was enormous, I barely got through half!
author: Chloe M.

description:
This place is usually open late, so if you are looking for late-night Pho, this would be one place to go to. Also, the Pho does taste pretty good.

Having said that, the kitchen is quite dirty. The bathroom is right next to the kitchen, and sometimes I see the wait staff take mops from inside the dirty bathroom to clean the kitchen, while others in the kitchen are still preparing food. The lack of separation between the kitchen and the dirty bathroom is very unsettling.
author: Henry L.

description:
Stopped in randomly on a nice day with the boyfriend. 

We stopped in JUST before the lunch rush, were seated right away. Given nice hot to sip on and our order was taken right away.

The Pho was FANTASTIC. We opted for the Mixed Seafood. 

Will NOT complain.

The photos on the walls are BEAUTIFUL. It makes me want to travel more.
author: Meghan L.

description: best BBQ chicken I've had. simple place but solid food. Combo A is now my favorite here
author: Roy O.

description: Extremely rude! I tried to pick up some food and was with my dog. I was apparently told (in a language I do not know) and with bright gestures that I was not welcomed in there. Asking nicely to leave my dog out would have been appropriate. They probably make too much money to treat people with such disrespect. It was extremely shocking. I used to go quite often but never again. Bye!
author: Anne P.

description: Good food, but very poor service.  Yelp doesn't like a one sentence review  it is accurate. Bad service really makes good food taste bad.  And that is a complete review, not a 'tip'.
author: Stephen P.

description:
I'm a big fan of pho, both of the South Vietnamese and North Vietnamese variety.

Pho Vung Tau has a pho dish that is unique and awesomely delicious. It's called the "Satay Beef Noodle Pho", Number 23, I believe. Get it. You won't be disappointed.

We are regulars here, and the ONLY thing we get is this unique, awesomely delicious, satay beef noodle pho. DON'T YOU DARE GET IT AS TAKE OUT!!! We tried ONCE and it wasn't nearly as good as the 30 times we've had it at the restaurant (when we sit down, she just knows what we want).

I've tried other dishes here, and they were all quite good, but this Satay Beef Noodle Pho is amazing. We crave it because we haven't come across it anywhere else.

Atmosphere is nothing, but it's a pho place in Chinatown. Set your expectations correctly and you won't be disappointed.
author: Joe P.

description: Very fast, kind service and cheap food. I chose this place because it also looks a lot cleaner than some of the other places nearby. Bbq pork on rice was absolutely delicious; the pork was juicy and perfectly cooked. Their mango juice is also very nice!
author: Melissa P.

description: Very best pork bun bowl I've ever had. Great service. Had a little trouble ordering as they didn't speak English but the menu was readable so we managed.
author: Sherri M.

description: I dropped by for a quick dinner after work. They greeted me cheerfully and seated me quickly, the service was fast. I ordered the vermicelli and it was delicious! I'm giving a 5 star rating  because the food was great, good price, and service was flawless. Also their Thai tea is really good.
author: Lorna L.

description: Service was okay but the bug in my Soup was undeniable. I guess i was unlucky. I didn't complain cause I'm asian but I hope this doesn't happen to other people.
author: Daryl Z.

description: north beach casual meal...returning to find pho vung tau...replacing chic-n-noodle-do vietnamese...returning with locals...taking recommendations...chicken and beef satay noodle soup requested...hot, rich and flavorful...good size and filling...the fried egg rolls on the other hand...decent, but quite thin...small and long...tasting mostly fried skin and very little filling...get a rich bowl of noodle soup at pho vung tau...
author: Hen A.

description: authentic, delicious, lovely people, pleasant service, reasonably priced, everything awesome for a neighborhood restaurant. I really love this restaurant and their two locations.
author: Bee S.

description:
I only come to this place because it is conveniently close to work.  Last Friday I ordered Bun Rieu and walked out smelling like Korean BBQ.  Their Bun Rieu is not authentic.  They give you half of a tomato with overcooked pork meatballs.  I don't remember seeing any tofu and question if there are any crab meat in this noodle soup at all.  Their imperial rolls are also really tiny, probably the size of an index finger for comparison.  

Overall, this place isn't bad for a quick bite, but I wouldn't walk in here expecting authentic Vietnamese food though.
author: Lynn L.

description:
Delicious Pho, and great ambience for our hidden Chinatown.  You know, the parts less travelled, and less filigree than the touristic attractions.  There are a few pho venues in this part that I have enjoyed. But this one. It's cozy and comforting, like sitting by the water stove on a chilly rainy SF day. The pho warms you up on the inside, and the environment cozy and quiet.

Great for a rainy day.
author: Mal S.

description: It's pretty good here! Their bowl portion is SO big, omg I could barely finish my bowl of pho, and I LOVE pho too. It's bigger than my head D; But overall, it taste so good, I'll be coming back here more often. My favorite pho place in chinatown :)
author: Sandy C.

description: I la la la la looooove this place. Their seafood pho is the best I've ever had! Their bbq pork chop is really good and their beef and broccoli. That what my family and I get whenever we go. I'm kinda sad that one of the waitress quit. She was my favorite. The new one is okay but I just go for the food that's it.
author: Marylou V.

description: The reviews looked ok so I tried this place. Ugh. The worst spring rolls I have ever had, and the steaming hot noodle soup didn't taste fresh. I do NOT recommend!
author: Michelle C.

description:
Food - CHEAP! Most things under $7 and huge portion size.

Their spring/shrimp/veg rolls are HUGE and make sure you get the peanut sauce.

I almost always do take-out. It seems to get crowded during lunch.

I'm always greeted kindly. They are nice and say goodbye and wish me well on my way out. Food comes relatively quick.

Not cash only but they rather not charge for under $10.

No tourists, ever.
author: Bunty S.

description: Best Vietnamese food anywhere! I am shocked this place isn't rated higher. Best Imperial rolls. Best soups, best everything! And I have had a lot of crappy Vietnamese. . .
author: Michael S.

description:
Vietnamese omelet is very interesting.
crispy egg wrap with chicken,shrimp and bean sprouts.
you would dip in the sauce and wrap in lettuce it's pretty good.

didn't like the curry noodle

chicken wings are ok.
author: Rina C.

description: Delicious Vietnamese food. You get exactly what you expect from a little whole in the wall place between Chinatown and North Beach. Fast service, polite staff, cheap food, good food! One of my go to place for lunch when I'm in the area.
author: Alexis S.

description:
After dropping by semi-consistently over a few months, I finally got a smile out of the owners! HAHA!

Regulars my coworkers and I get:
#20 - simple pho with meatballs, steak and brisket
#50 - lemongrass beef vermicelli bowl - ton of noodles, good portion of seasoned sauce-y beef, onions and red chilis (don't eat them!!!) and fish sauce
#61 - pork chop, bbq chicken, fried egg over rice with fish sauce. My usual order :)

This place is not about ambiance, it is in a grimy part of North Beach/Chinatown and doesn't have that many tables. If you come during the later part of lunch time (near 1 p.m.) be prepared to wait. What? Wait? There's a reason for that. Most dishes are under $7, come with hot jasmine/oolong tea, and come out relatively fast. 

Caveat - you will have to stand up and do some sort of dance for them to bring you your check. Many times I've just walked up to the counter and asked to pay. But you know what? I don't even care. 

It can get pretty loud with Cantonese in here, and whenever I'm there it's 95% Asians. LOL at you if you were expecting white tablecloth and overly attentive service with a smile just because this place exists in San Francisco. They are polite to you if you are polite to them but please realize you are paying less than $8 for a meal and there are a ton of people in here to serve (2 waitresses only), end of story. 

CASH ONLY.
author: Stephanie M.

description:
Wow this place's menu looks amazing.  Appetizers, soup, so many noodles, vermicelli, rice plates, etc.   And its cheap too.  Dac biet noodles soup for 6.95,  comes with a salad.  6 egg rolls for 5.95.

The soup however, is only so so, doesn't have that rich beef broth taste, I guess next time i  should order rice plates with the grilled meat instead.  The egg rolls skin is kinda chewy.    Iced coffee is not strong enough; they put very little expresso in the cup.
author: Tadaa T.

description: Great food taste just like home cooking. But beware they always seem to run out of ice??
author: Linda B.

description: I'm Vietnamese , this place sucks . Bad service , they are not even close to qualified to making pho .  This place would ruin  Cup O Noodles ! No parking . No drinks on the menu were available . I have nothing nice to say about this dump .
author: Bruce L.

description:
I love this place. We have been coming here last 6 years . Always good food and servers are always kind. 
Me and my son go for Pho almost every week and my son loves this place. 
Recently they increased their price $1 for every menu. It was $6.99 now is $7.99 which is still very affordable in the city and their portion is huge.
I always share a bowl with my son and we are still very happy with it!
author: Jimin K.

description: I usually come to this place because it's convenient and their pho isn't half bad. The broth is a little bland so if you don't like your soup to be too rich this might be a good place for you. Imperial rolls are meh. They are long and skinny and don't have too much filling in them but taste-wise they're not bad. Normally I would rate this a 3 or 4, but I was a little upset over my food during my most recent trip. It was around 11 in the morning, still rather quiet with a few people scattered around the restaurant. I ordered the chicken pho and they brought it out soon after. Upon closer inspection, I noticed that there was a strand of hair in my soup! I alerted the waitress, she apologized, and brought the bowl to the back. A few minutes later she brought out a new bowl of pho, and when I was mixing my vegetables and noodles, lo and behold, ANOTHER strand of hair. Now there can be two possible explanations: either the cook is balding and desperately needs to wear a hairnet if they're going to be working with food or they never switched my food out to begin with. Either way, something needs to be fixed. Won't be coming back for a long time.
author: Jennifer K.

description:
This is my go-to Vietnamese restaurant whenever I'm in the area. Portions are big and the food is CHEAP.

The service is relatively attentive. However, definitely flag the waiter down if you need anything. 

Five Spice Chicken w/ Vermicelli - The chicken was delicious. The skin was crispy and they do not skimp on portions. The vermicelli noodles tasted fresh. The Nuoc Cham was pretty good as well. 

Imperial Rolls - smaller in size but good nonetheless

Grilled Pork Salad - The pork was in bits and pieces. However, it was seasoned well. The salad was dressed well and the portion was big. It was filling!

Chicken Salad - I loved this. However, note the chicken is not seasoned. It is simply shredded chicken.
author: Carol W.

description:
Had rare beef Pho the broth had a unique cinamon/anise type of flavor that I could not pinpoint not in a bad way just unique.

Overall goood  pho but not the best I've had
author: Manny R.

description: Came here and I ordered the Imperial Roll and BBQ Pork Vermicelli and it  tasted very good with the right flavoring. The service was quick and the waitress was friendly and let us change the TV channel. This place is very affordable with big portions for the price you pay for. I would come back and try more different things on their menu.
author: Peter C.

description:
Finally tried this restaurant after passing by it so many times. Came on a Saturday around 1 and it was pretty packed. There was a group ahead of us but we got seated  right away. I doubt the authenticity of how Vietnamese it is since the waitresses were Chinese but maybe the chef is Viet? Ehh who knows. We ordered a #27 and what would be a #1 in other pho restaurants but here, it's #20 or something, and a Thai iced tea. #27 was a spicy beef stew with egg noodles and it was alright, but there was a layer of oil floating in the soup and it wasn't spicy :( I tried some of the #20 and the noodles weren't as chewy as I like it... Their tea that they use to make the Thai iced tea must've been steeped for too long because the color of the drink was wayyyy too dark. I  guessed that they didn't have time to make it right since they only have 2 waitresses working. 

All together the bill was around $17. You will like this place if you prefer something other than beef pho
author: Angela H.

description:
The vegetarian spring rolls are awesome! I've now had them twice.
They satisfy my ongoing spring roll craving.
I guess you could say I'm on a roll.
author: Eva UnTiger S.

description:
Great quality at great prices! The food always is prepared as before!
Very kind employees too. Always busy which is a good sign!
Chicken pho is really good! All their combo specials. A lot of food for your money.
author: Larry L.

description: The food quality is pretty decent. My parents and I usually eat here when we are in the Chinatown area. I have gotten their bun bo hue and I enjoyed it. My mom got the seafood pho which was supposed to come with shrimp and she only got a puny one. She told the waitress and she got some more for her so I guess that was nice. No small or large, there is only one size so prepare to be full afterwards. However, the service is a tad slow. Usually have to wait about 20 mins for the food to come out after ordering.
author: Mimi S.

description: All of the noodle soup my family ordered are so bland...this is waste of time and money...just so happened to pass by it and was so hungry but our hunger did not help make the food taste any good...
author: Richard O.

description:
I'm amazed this restaurant has only 3 and a half stars! I'm sorry but I love this place. This restaurant sits in the hidden parts of Chinatown. We were a bit reluctant to dine there for lunch as yelp reviewers gave it an average of 3 1/2 stars but we were on a time limit. 

It was about 10:30ish and we were quite hungry! My family and I walked into a small empty shop and was kindly greeted by a sweet lady. She immediately gave us complimentary green Jasmine tea which was much needed on a breezy San Francisco morning. 

Typically, I always order Vietnamese pho at a Vietnamese restaurant but I was craving rice. So, I ordered their BBQ Pork Over Rice in their "Rice Plate" category. Oh me, oh my... It definitely hit the spot. The rest of my family were quite pleased with their plates, too.

Lastly, the only server in the restaurant were quick, efficient, and very friendly.
author: Sovana L.

description:
This is mostly the BEST vietnam resturant EVER! Trust me , i know. 

The other review I see say there isn't much FLAVOR in the soup. Let me tell you WHY. All the other vietnamese resturant add ALOT MSG in their soup and this resutrant add only very little MSG  with natural Ingredients. 

This resturant is the cheapest also and Highly reccomend this because it is VERY STUFFING! 

RECOMMEND WHAT TO ORDER FOR THE NEW FOLKS: BEEF NODDLE SOUP! 

Friendly service also!
author: Julie M.

description: So I've only came here to eat the pho usually since its close to where I get my hair cut. I don't have any complaints here since the pho seems decent here and the portion is well sized for the price. I may try the rice plates and other things since that is what other people seem to talk about. But the broth isn't overly salty and the noodle to meat proportion seems equal, not too much of anything. Ingredients like the bean sprouts seem clean and fresh. Overall the food here is pretty good, service is okay. For a place in Chinatown though, it's pretty darn clean! I still probably won't eat off the table if something fell, but it's cleaner and not sticky like other places in Chinatown. Overall, worth a try!
author: Johnson S.

description:
I love coming here for lunch. This is one of the cleanest pho places i know. The service is great, the food is fresh, not like the last one I went to where I lost my brackets on my braces fell of because of the chicken being very hard. The food here is nothing like that, the chicken is tender and the noodles are fresh. I really recommend eating here if you are around the area. The prices are very affordable if you are looking to pay under 7 bucks for some pho with a lot of meat. 

I full for 7 bucks.

5 stars from me, keep the meat, noodles and veggies fresh and I'll keep coming back.
author: mrhustler h.

description: So we order a squid salad to start and share before our 2 bowls of pho. The salad comes out and it smells like an overnight trash bin from a seafood market. We point this out to the server who was very apologetic then the female owner or manager comes out and starts yelling NOTHING WRONG WITH SALAD, YOU PAY, YOU HAVE TO PAY. It was like a frickin" comedy skit, quite hilarious. I left and had a great lunch a block away at Yuet Lee.
author: gene f.

description: Tucked onto the fault line between North Beach and Chinatown, this place is pretty solidly three-stars. This is one of those places where Chinese people run a non-Chinese restaurant, they'll make the portions HUGE. Cantonese-speakers abound in the kitchen and they dish out decent food. I've had their satay chicken noodle soup and their lemongrass chicken vermicelli bowl. I kept eyeing the random $8 platters that they have for lunch specials. Looks like a lot of food and I just might try it next time.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Yep, I am giving Pho Vung Tau 5 stars.

For $8 and some odd change you get:

-BBQ pork
-Rice or Vermicelli
-3 jumbo fried shrimp
-A coleslaw-like salad
-2 mini egg rolls

They bring tea when you sit down, I always have to request water. The BBQ pork is seriously excellent, and I think about it sometimes when I know I can't have it. The meat is thin and all the flavors blend together excellently. The weird thing is, when you take food to go (which I always do when I go here) they charge .25 for a to-go box. This is fine and all, but why don't they charge .25 when you take it to-go?
author: Kristin F.

description:
Very average. 

I opted for the veggie tofu pho sans shrooms. 

Service was friendly enough. Not over the top, but it was certainly attentive enough to make the meal an overall pleasant experience.

We were the only table there at 8pm on a Friday night. I'm not entirely surprised. 

If I lived nearby, I might do take out when I'm craving quick, relatively inexpensive Vietnamese food, but I'm not going out of my way to go there again.
author: Monica C.

description:
cheap Vietnamese sandwiches within a few blocks of work = WIN

However, my one twu wuv, is their Bun Rieu. It hits the spot soo well, I don't even bother ordering their other pho anymore. Delicious, Crab Meat Tomato Noodle Soup. Yes, maybe it's a little oily. Yes, maybe I have a food coma post-bun rieu, but I love it too much. I order it with the pho noodles instead of vermicelli, and they're always very accomodating. The meat is some sort of chopped up marinated goodness with crab paste. I've tried Bun Rieu at the two other pho places nearby, and I'm pretty sure Pho Vung Tau's Bun Rieu is not as authentic as it should be after wiki-ing the ingredients. Still, I think it's my favorite one. One of these days, I'll need to try the Bun Bo Hue (spicy beef noodle soup), but it's hard for me to stray from my usual deliciousness.. 

Rainy days make me think of that delicious soup and I can't help heading over to PVT. Even when they're packed during lunch service, the wait is never too long. The service is friendly and fast, food affordable and delicious. They will kick people out fast if others are waiting, but when there's no rush, you could sit there for a bit with some tea. The island decor/wallpaper is interesting. I sometimes stare at it wishing I was there.. and then I snap out of it and head back to work.. where the food coma begins.. *slump*
author: Donna H.

description:
Good food, good service = 5 stars.

Not a high end restaurant, but who cares.. i've been to high end restaurant only to get served by bit*hy waitress.. This place is actually a good place to go.

We had some questions on the kind of noodles they use, and the waiter went through the trouble to go inside the kitchen and brought out a piece of noodle to show us the type. She also offered us to choose any kind of noodle that we want to go with any of the pho dish. When we made an order, she was afraid that we might not like it, and actually explained it very clearly what we're getting to make sure we won't hate it, which we ordered anyway and the food was good.
author: Boib H.

description: My favorite restaurant in San Francisco. Food tastes so good and cheap. I probably come here more than three times a week. I would say Pho Vung Tau is one of the best restaurant in North Beach area.
author: Roo K.

description: I'll have to upgrade again.  I was not intending on going here, but my desired place was unexpectedly closed.  I went for the #37, BBQ port vermicelli bowl-a staple of these spots.  Really a nice amount and great taste.  Fair price.  Most importantly, I did not feel ill like I sometimes do after Vietnamese food which means they didn't use MSG or made it too salty.  I'd stay away from the fried imperial roll options and just stick to the basics here.  As in my previous review, the 5 spice chicken here is real nice as well.  $8.50 with tip, free tea.  Nice toothpicks at table.
author: Marc S.

description:
Food tasted good, great portions, service quick and pleasant! The Imperial rolls are on the small side but considering how good the rest of the food is, I recommend a visit. I was surprised about the combination plates, a good introduction to their quantity and quality. The BBQ pork with imperial rolls on noodles was very good to.

By the way, go early because it packs up quickly.
author: Carol M.

description: This place serves one of the best Satay Beef Noodle Pho I've had in a while. The place looks pretty clean and service is average but nice. Serving size is above average for San Francisco. I'm impressed.
author: Johnny D.

description:
I've had pho from many different places, I'd have to say this is somewhere in the middle of the pack.  Broth was decent, beef wasn't great, but overall it tasted pretty good.  It did take awhile for me to get my soup though, and no one else was ordering while I was in there?  I guess this could be taken as a good sign, but I figured if a pho place was legit they had a huge pot ready for action in the back.  All they needed to do was throw in a hunk of noodles, some beef, and a handful of veggies.  But seriously, 15 min for this to happen?  

Also, the server was wearing those super thin white gloves.  I don't understand why people around here do that at stores.  I don't care if you have the cleanest hands/gloves this side of the Pacific.  It still grosses me out beyond belief and makes me want to return whatever you gave to me with those putrid gloves on.  Ugh.  That is a large part of what brought this place down for me.
author: William B.

description:
I am a fan!  This is one of those mom and pops shops that never fail to feed me... except when they're closed.  The portions are filling and it doesn't make a huge dent in your wallet.  Let's see...  I've been here several times now since I live super close.  Sometimes it's swarming packed - weekends...  sometimes I feel like I'm the only one who gives this place business - early weekdays...

What's good?

Vietnamese Sandwiches here are actually quite tasty!!!!  I would suggest trying them all...  The bun is all toasted, the meat of choice is seasoned well and succulent, the veggies actually add to the sandwich instead of thinking "why do they stuff so many stems in here?!" and it's only $3.50.

The combination meals are really good too.  There's a lot on that plate once it gets to you.  The Pho is pretty good too and hot!  Can't have soup without seeing some steam rise from it...

SO yeah, go here and try it!  I'll be back here soon enough...
author: Limzer L.

description:
Good hot bowls of pho. 
Cleaner than average Asian eatery in Chinatown.   
The 'step up' on cleanliness is a big plus for me.  
Prices are cheap too.

(I get tired of many other places with the greasy, dirty tables and needing to wipe your plate before you use it.)
author: Kev M.

description: Happened to take a chance on this place. Doesn't look like the cleanest restaurant but that's usually the type with the best food. Ordered the shrimp rolls, Dac Biet bowl, and wifey got the seafood jean mein. Surprisingly, the entrees were pretty good, but the shrimp roll bordered on bland. The mein came out shaped like a bird's nest so that was unique. Don't order the viet sandwiches as there's more bread than meat in it. Prices overall were on the low end. Good place for lunch but watch out for rude chinese patrons. We'll still be back.
author: Hagow C.

description:
Bang for Buck!

In the North Beach area and overwhelmed by all the foreign scribbles offering "best *insert food item here*?!"   

If you're in the mood for can't-go-wrong, on the cheap Vietnamese eats, Pho Vung Tao is the place to go.   Has a "hole in the wall feel", but is spacious, extremely clean, and has friendly and fast service!

This place can satiate ALL your Viet desires as it offers ban mi, bun, AND pho in addition to many other rice, seafood, and stir fry dishes. 

Big shrimp rolls are neatly presented and come with delish peanut sauce for $4!  Beef and imperial roll verm bowl is obscenely flavorful and will fill your tum for $8 (regular, non combo verm bowls are $7).

My new go to when I'm too tired to cook! Yay!

$Average $6.50 per entree.  ($3.50 ban mi sandwiches!)
author: Jane L.

description:
When I come here the only thing I get is the Pho Bo Dac Biet... which is the Special Beef noodle soup.  It has a decent taste and good portions.  

I dont recommend the Bun here because it is mostly vermicelli noodles.. lacks the veggies.. meat... and the egg rolls are tiny.. I goto My Canh for that on broadway.
author: Jasen L.

description: The mung bean and coconut milk drink was a wonderful and refreshing introduction to what I was about to experience.  The enormous, piping-hot bowl of BBQ beef pho arrived before me with all of the necessary fixings; I only wish it were smaller so I could have had room to try more items, like the delicious-looking Vietnamese sandwiches.  The staff was attentive enough to cater to a consistent ebb-and-flo crowd as well, and the free green tea was a lovely gesture.
author: Scott V.

description:
I spent a total of $5 here on lunch. Total. I know. It's tough to spend only $5 on lunch, especially a good lunch, hereabouts.

A pork Banh-Mi (Vietnamese sammich) costs $3. It's on the smaller side, but I didn't walk away hungry. I had plenty left over for some gelato at nearby Naia, which actually cost more than my lunch. 

The walls are island-themed and made me feel like I was on vacation. Everything else is pretty standard fare for a Vietnamese resto, but most Vietnamese restos aren't this cheap.
author: Tara R.

description: For the low prices and fresh tasting food, I would definitely return.
author: Valerie K.

description: Service was great, food very tasty with generous helpings.  The only issue we had was that they close at 9pm and by 8:50 or so when we wanted another cup of tea they told us they had already thrown it out.  Otherwise it was great!
author: Brad G.

description:
I live around the corner, and this is the best pho I have found in North Beach yet... 

That being said, it's not great when compared to some REAL good pho.  Apart from a sprinklihng of rice dishes, I've stuck to the "special beef soup", my staple at any pho place.  

They go a little heavy on the noodles, and a little light on the meat.  The broth is pretty tasty, but only if your standards are low.  I was pretty happy with the sprouts and basil and such... definately fresh and haven't been sitting around (they probably buy these daily next door!). 

The best deal they have here is are the fresh shrimp springrolls.   The thai places around have them too, but for more money and less spring roll!  These are huge, the peanut sauce is yummy and you just can't go wrong!

All in all a nice meal for the cheap price it is.  I get it to go whenever I"m sick.
author: Joseph F.

description:
Pho Vung Tau is one of those interloper Vietnamese restaurants in San Francisco's Chinatown, sneaking in amongst the bajillion dim-sum joints and BBQ places that line Stockton Street. My friend Natasha and I decided to head for Vietnamese food though, gosh darn it, and I'm glad we did. What a nice little place! I am also partial to their tropical themed-signs and the palm-tree and grass-hut festooned wall hanging inside. What can I say, I'm a sucker for am-bience.



I tried the Satay Seafood Soup. It tasted like an Indonesian riff on your usual Vietnamese rice noodle soup and was really very tasty indeed, with a nice spicy hit of coconut milk and (what seemed) like a little bit of peanut. Seafood was plentiful, if a little heavy on the fish cakes. As it happens, I love me some fish cakes, so this was by no means a bad thing.



We shared the Shrimp Salad, a pretty classic Vietnamese salad composed of cabbage, pickled carrot and radish, fried shallot, and peanut, as well as mint and cilantro. This came with a nice light fish sauce dressing and was a good cool counterpoint to the soups.

Natasha had the Vermicelli Bowl With Beef. This was one of the most humongo vermicelli bowls I've ever encountered, and she said the beef was tender and delicious.

Pho Vung Tau is a nice option for Vietnamese food in the depths of Chinatown. Good food, good prices, and a clean open kitchen: what's not to like? 

photos here: http://teenagechowhound.blogspot.com/
author: faine g.

description: This is my favorite Vietnamese restaurant in San Francisco. I eat here almost every week. The Pho is good, and the barbeque pork over vermicelli is amazing.
author: Emma M.

description: I come here all the time for lunch... very yummy.  Their bbq pork & vermicelli are crave worthy.  The staff are friendly and the service is quick.
author: Melissa B.

description: It's a hole in the wall place, but it's a standard spot for me and my roommate. Everything there is super tasty and we've always had good service. It's also really clean and the prices are great. Definitely one of my favorite spots in Chinatown.
author: Rinki S.

description:
Here's the scoop... I'm not a pho snob, but  I do like pho and think I know good from bad as well as great!  I've pho'd it up.

I normally stick with pho ga.  This place makes a delicious south Vietnamese pho (more chicken, stronger broth, and all the garnishes).  The broth was so hot (as it should be) that I nearly finished all my egg rolls before I could even slurp.  Oh the egg rolls...  came with all the dressings (mint, carrot, lettuce, etc) and were excellent.

I walked out the door for $14 (including tip).
author: Marc H.

description: Returned today with a friend while walking around hungry for food and fotos. Had the combo B which included steamed rice with BBQ Pork with seemingly spicy sauce but amazing not; two spring rolls (yummy) and three shrimp, and a cole-slaw salald which my friend ate only, with two cups of tea. Very quick service and quite tasty. Paid less than $8.60 with tax included so was a very good deal and so quick in being served. I must state that the floor, tables and chairs were all very clean with a very prompt waitress coming to take our order as soon as we walked in. The general appearance of the overall cleanliness is a great change from the nearby pasta/italian places with filthy sticky floors, and tables and chairs together dirty and tacky to the touch that i even use a napkin to clean both and get the napkin blackened within seconds. Street parking which is rarely available. Paid parking garage across the street; if you have a problem with anything, the SFPD is further up the street past the alley  ;^)
author: Tony L.

description:
The name isn't as snazzy as Chick-n-Noodle-Do, but the food is good and the prices are just as reasonable as the previous Chinese-Vietnamese joint that used to be here!  My co-workers and I frequent this restaurant at least once a week and appreciate the variety.  Some co-workers enjoy the vermicelli bowls and others the hefty rice combo plates, but my personal favorites are the #11 BBQ Pork Sandwich (gotta love the flaky French roll and the $3.50 price tag) and the #24 Beef Pho.

Unlike the filthy Vietnamese restaurants on Broadway, the interiors here are pristine.  Not as erratically adorned with puzzles & Asian-pop-IKEA decor like it once was in the days of Chick-n-Noodle, there are huge wallpaper murals of the mother country instead (fun for daydreaming).  Come in for lunch and feast your eyes on all the crappy daytime TV on their television set too.
author: Andrea U.

description:
I had to kill time while waiting for my tow truck to arrive so I decided to eat across the street in the unfamiliar Chinatown of San Francisco.  Again, this place was very clean.  Maybe a new trend for Pho places?  But, since it was clean, it didn't just have Asians in there.

I ordered the 5 Spice Chicken with Rice with 2 Egg Rolls, 3 Fried Shrimp, Salad and a side of broth.

I was really disappointed with the rice.  It was steamed rice and not Jasmine rice.  The egg rolls and fried shrimps were good though but then again, just drop in the oil and take it out when you think it's ready.  The ration of the chicken was very meager and very oily.  The biggest portion on the plate would definitely have been the salad and the rice.  The soup was just not great at all.

The most amusing part of my meal was watching these 2 Chinese ladies paying for the entire meal with pennies, nickels and dimes.  They had to save their quarters for the laundry machine, I assume.  LOL, 'nuff said.  I wouldn't go back again, but then again, I never go to Chinatown.
author: David K.

description: I come here almost twice a week! There Vietnamese food  is AWSOME!! I love there Number #61! (:
author: Jonathan Z.

description:
I can't complain about this place because it's basically "Tuesday" in my work week. It used to be the old Noodle Doo and basically sticks to the same menu of items... even 42 remains 42 (which I believe is universal in all vietnamese restaurants). They did get rid of the random puzzle pictures and replaced it with a huge picture of a beach... assumably (?) Vietnam. Tip: there's a topless woman in the picture!!! (Yes, I found it and me and my coworkers acted real mature afterwards)

The lady who runs it is awesome and hilarious. Not only does she know each item and its menu number by heart but also she greets and "recites" the same dialog to everyone  in exactly the same tone! Anyway, she's already pegged me and my order which never changes... lemongrass chicken over rice! The dish is great... garlic, green beans, and chicken all stir fried into awesome goodness. It probably scores a 0 on the health factor but it's worth it for a warm filling lunch on a brisk SF day.

I've had the lemongrass beef as well but the chicken is better in my opinion. The combo platters are decent but a little way too much food... plus the fried shrimp really is just pure batter anyway.
author: Jonny Bobby G.

description: I've been here 3 times. My first two experiences were pretty good. I always order the BBQ beef over vermicelli. The last two times I've order it without peanuts just because of the fact I don't like having peanuts in there. I'm not allergic or anything. I prefer eating it without peanuts. When I was there today, I've told the lady that I want it without peanuts. She asked me again to confirm and I said yes. When my order came, there were peanuts in it. So I've just scooped it out and put it aside. I've ran out of tea twice. The first time I've had to ask twice and they refilled it for me. The second time I've asked 5 times and no one refilled it. So I've paid for my meal and just left. I wouldn't be coming here anytime soon.
author: Tiffany Y.

description:
This place is under new ownership (formerly Chic-n-Noodle-Do).  I used to go for the vietnamese sandwiches, so called up the same # as on my old takeout menu, only to find a #20 Grilled Chicken Sandwich was some sort of rice with pork plate.  

nonetheless, the confusion was cleared when i figured out it was a new place with a new menu.

the sandwich bread was very soft and good, however i was looking for something more toasted (but not the hard crusty seemingly day-old bread you find at other joints).  the grilled chicken was very moist and they actually gave me a decent amount.  overall the sandwich was worth getting again, especially at $3.50.  for the record, i was hoping for some jalapenos which i didn't see any of.  they also didnt give me any napkins in my takeout brown bag, but then again what should i expect, it IS chinatown.

i would definitely go back, it's a little bit cleaner looking (new owners either cleaned up or did some moderate remodeling), but don't expect a drastic change in the quality of food, its nothing high-class, its just your run-of-the-mill vietnamese food, though in my opinion, one of the better places still in northbeach.
author: Jason J.

description:
This place really does a great job on dishes and rice plates.  

Some of the things I really like about this place are:

* It's clean
* It has a relatively clean bathroom which is very rare in Chinatown
* The people there are friendly and they remember me
* They do a nice job of presenting the food
* They have nicer plates than many similar restaurants
* They are attentive
* The food is clearly prepared with care
* The prices are reasonable
* They are open later that other places in the area
* They have nice pictures of Vietnam on the wall

The could use a bit of improvement on their pho.  They use the thin noodles that neither my girlfriend or I like which are a bit too chewy.   I suggest they make a weekend visit to Turtle Tower in the Tenderloin for tips on how to improve their Pho. With better soups this place would move from a 4 to a 5 in my book.

I plan to be a regular here for years to come.  This place deserves a loyal following as they really do a good job.
author: Ken P.

description:
We got the special beef pho and shrimp with broccoli a half an hour ago and there is not a morsel left.  Even the funky sausage like sponge thing in the pho is down the hatch.  

Eh, it was cheap Vietnamese but I enjoyed it.  I will go back.

Heads up: CASH ONLY
author: Hayley W.

description: shrimp roll is good and thats all i get wen im here lol. im pretty sure the food is good and will come back since its in the neighborhood my friend lives in
author: Linda A.

description: i've been coming to this place for a long time and they don't disappoint!! i usually  have dinner there but my hubby decided to have lunch.OMG the place was packed but it was a short wait . the food is as good  as it was. the seafood noodle soup the broth is the DA BOMB!!!
author: Jo K.

description: I went to Pho Vung Tau for the first time and ordered what I normally order at Vietnamese restaurants, the #1 Beef noodle soup. It was pretty delicious. At least delicious enough to make me want to drink the soup. The service was not bad either.
author: Forest T.

description: This is my favorite viets restaurant to go and i always order the bun rieu ,beef stew and pho duhhhh LOL!!! very clean and friendly
author: alan l.

description: Well run by a couple of very sweet Vietnamese ladies.  Consistently great food, good prices, very friendly service.  Also much cleaner and more comfortable than many authentic little pho shops.
author: Duke K.

description: i usually ordered to-go from there and it's reasonably price. i was there once in eating the clay pot rice in one of the Friday night.  the only problem is the space very small, it's very crowd in there during lunch time.
author: Mike T.

description: I got food poisoning from eating the beef stew at this place. Felt sick, got home and threw up twice. Second time I threw up BLOOD. Obviously there is something wrong with their food. Went to see a doctor and now I have an infection in my stomach. AVOID at all cost if you want to keep your health.
author: Joseph N.

description:
We are so excited to have this (relatively new) offering in our neighborhood!  We live right around the corner and this is our new go-to joint for vietnamese food (and for dinner when we haven't planned ahead).  unlike a lot of the food we can order, this stuff leaves us feeling relatively healthy after we eat it.  never greasy or heavy, it's so, so tastey.   
the fresh shrimp (or vegetarian) spring rolls are huge and filling, only $5 for 2.  the shrimp salad (with lot's of crisp cabage and carrots) knocks our socks off for $6.  
you can't beat the Satay Chicken Noodle Soup (for $6.25).  it's enough to share.  i suspect the chicken used in this soup is actually the "5 spice" chicken, but the quality is so good you will not quibble with subtle flavour discrepancies.  this dish is full of flavorful, tender roasted chicken.
our other favorites are "grilled shrimp with vermicelli" and "garlic eggplant over rice."
another thing we appreciate about Pho Vung Tau is that the lovely ladies who work there allow us to bring our own containers for our dishes.  we have quite enough "restaurant tupperware" already and it feels good to reuse it instead of creating demand for more plastic.
this place is cheap and delicious.  the staff is cheerful and accomodating.  there is a slight communication barrier, but nothing you can't handle.  they're open every day!  
now GO and eat there!  we hope they get lots of business so that they never leave our neighborhood.  we've come to depend on them for last minute "i forgot to shop," "i don't have time to cook," "I'm hungry NOW," dinner that we can feel good about and doesn't break the bank.
author: passion f.

description: I am super picky about my shrimp and pork rolls and have tried most of them in the city.  The best thing is that Pho Vung Tau's are actually some of the best and only 2 blocks from my house.  Their Pho is really good as well - a great meal for a cold, rainy night in SF.  I wish they had delivery though, then I would give a 5!
author: michelle s.

description: I found this small place when searching for something good to eat in the area. I had the beef Pho and it was very very good. Service is excellent.
author: J N.

description:
i was here on Thursday night a friend, we did not know what to get everything looked so good. my friend had rice and beef with vegetables for $7.50 and seemed to enjoy it, i had one of the plates in the pictures outside. it was good but did not fill me so much i wanted to order something else. 

place could be a bit larger
author: sergio f.

description: i'll try not to let joseph's review sway me (although, it is a bit concerning). the 3 times i've been here i've really liked the pho.... their beef stew is just spicy enough (if you're not a big spice fan) and there's a lot to make you full. also, as mentioned before, the restaurant is a lot more clean than the other vietnamese restaurants in the area. if there's one bad thing about the place, it's that the beef they use is really fatty (more fatty than beef chuck), but if you're not keen on premium grade beef, this is great!
author: Simon L.

description: I would give this place 4.5 stars if the rating system would let me. First of all let me make the disclaimer that this is not haute cuisine - you don't walk into a mom and pop diner expecting a gourmet meal, neither would you expect that walking into this small, clean little place in North Beach. In a neighborhood of pretty dingy, sketchy looking places, this restaurant stood out at first sight as being quite clean. Ordered the special beef noodle soup and egg rolls. Pretty good flavor to the egg rolls. Rolled up with some fresh herbs and lettuce, pickled radish and carrot and dipped in that concoction of fish sauce and such it hit the spot. Special Beef Noodle pho had a good flavor to the broth, lots of noodles and lots of meat. Meat was pretty decent quality. The meatballs were pretty tasty too (didn't have those crunchy bits of sinew you sometimes find with cheaper meatballs). All in all a great cheap little place for lunch - would definitely go back (although I wouldn't make a special trip for it)
author: Sung P.

description: good vietnamese food, every thing cook to order, ate there twice.cheap ,nice portions.
author: carl h.

description: I really like this place.   It looks pretty clean and the old ladies who run it are nice and friendly.  They have these large prints of tropical beaches on the walls and a large TV in the corner so that doesn't hurt either.  The pho dishes are always a safe bet.  The cold noodle dishes are ok too.  It could do with a bit more sauce and a bit less noodle, but it wasn't a big deal.  It's a great place to catch a casual lunch.  I live in the neighborhood, so it's nice to pop in and grab some lunch.  You can even watch TV or flip through a magazine while you wait.
author: Raz R.

description: Really fresh and delicious vegetarian spring rolls and vegetarian bun.  Nice atmosphere.
author: Barbara A.
